I.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will provide a concessional loan of $30 million loan 
from its ordinary capital resources for subprogram 1 of the  Financial Market Development 
Program.1 The indicative loan amount for subprogram 2 is $30 million from ADB’s concessional 
ordinary capital resources. The program aims to help the Government of Bhutan adopt timely 
reforms to enhance the efficiency, stability, and inclusiveness of the finance sector. The program 
will support the government with implementing institutional reforms and will build the technical 
capacity of regulators and financial institutions. 
 
2.  The proposed program’s impact will be the improved economic welfare of the Bhutanese 
people, especially women, through increased employment, private sector business development, 
enhanced access to finance, and greater efficiency of financial intermediation. By 2023, the total 
value of outstanding bonds is expected to reach Nu9.3 billion (about $130 million), an increase of 
7% from the 2018 baseline. This year-on-year growth of private sector credit provided by 
commercial banks will increase from the average 2014–2018 baseline rate of 14.7% to at least 
an average of 17.0% for 2019–2023. The percentage of adults who have access to credit will 
reach at least 18.0% by 2023 compared to the 16.0% baseline of 2018. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The  transaction technical  assistance (TA)  is  necessary  to  effectively  implement the 
program. ADB has consistently recognized and responded to Bhutan’s substantial need and 
demand for capacity building, the result of limited capacity and access to best practices among 
government agencies. Continued reforms and new policies in the finance sector are necessary to 
support Bhutan’s transition toward middle-income status. Past experience also confirms that ADB 
TA has not only facilitated the achievement of policy-based programs’ reform actions, but that it 
has also generated incremental reforms.2 The transaction TA will help the government formulate 
regulations and guidelines to implement the three areas of reform under the program, build the 
capacity of the government agencies and financial institutions to implement the reforms under 
subprogram 2 of the program, and provide training and capacity building to entrepreneurs and 
the disadvantaged to promote financial inclusion. The transaction TA is listed in the country 
operations business plan for Bhutan, 2019–2021 (footnote 1).3 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
4.  The TA outputs will map major policy actions under the program and be implemented over 
27 months from December 2019 to March 2022. The TA will engage a total of 12 person-months 
of international consultancy services and 14 person-months of national consultancy services; the 
consultants will work closely with the government, other relevant stakeholders, and ADB. The TA 
will cover the following three outputs. 
 
5.  Output 1: Strategies and regulations developed. The TA will support the executing and 
implementing agencies in

2021. Manila. 
2 Independent Evaluation Department. 2019. Validation of the Country Partnership Strategy Final Review, 2014–2018 
in Bhutan. Manila: ADB.

2 
(i)  formulating rules and regulations for long-term government bond issuance; 
(ii) preparing regulatory frameworks and background analyses to revise rules and regulations 
for corporate bond and commercial paper issuance; 
(iii) formulating a long-term strategy for public housing with financing mechanisms to promote 
affordable housing for disadvantaged groups, including women;   
(iv) formulating amendments to the Financial Services Act 2011, including provisions allowing 
for composite insurance by insurance companies; 
(v) formulating the rules and regulations on licensing requirements for pension and provident 
fund service providers; and 
(vi) formulating  the  revised  the  Prudential  Regulations  2017  to  incorporate  International 
Financial Reporting Standard 9 on impairment of loans.4 
 
6.  Output 2: Capacity of financial institutions and their supervisors strengthened. The 
TA will support the executing and implementing agencies in  
(i)  building  the  Ministry  of  Finance’s  capacity  and  knowledge  on  the  procedures  and 
sequencing steps and analytical tools required on issuing debt instruments and public debt 
management; 
(ii) building the capacity of the Royal Monetary Authority (RMA) and financial institutions in 
establishing systems, mechanisms, and procedures to implement an online anti-money 
laundering reporting system; and 
(iii) building the RMA’s capacity to improve risk-based supervision, including implementing 
risk profiling and assessment of commercial banks and insurance companies. 
 
7.  Output  3:  Knowledge  and  capacity  of  entrepreneurs  and  the  disadvantaged 
increased. With the aim of raising the public's financial literacy levels in alignment with the 
National Financial Inclusion Strategy, 2018–2023 and the National Financial Literacy Strategy, 
2018–2023,5 the TA will develop supporting systematic mechanisms for the RMA to carry out a 
financial literacy program to increase the capacity of entrepreneurs and disadvantaged groups in 
accessing finance by 
(i)  developing and implementing a gender-targeted financial literacy program; 
(ii) expanding the financial literacy curriculum framework beyond mainstream education and 
local government to include nonformal education and technical vocational education and 
training; 
(iii) developing a strategy for warehouse receipt financing to promote better access to finance, 
enabling farmers to use the receipts as collateral; and 
(iv) assisting the introduction of innovative financing schemes, such as an inclusive green 
finance scheme, to promote access to finance by entrepreneurs seeking funding for 
environment-friendly projects. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
8.  The TA is estimated to cost $525,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 1.

9.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transport, and other in-kind 
contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s South Asia Department will select, supervise, and 
evaluate consultants, and procure goods.
